channel.title: Global News Podcast
channel.description: The day’s top stories from BBC News. Delivered twice a day on weekdays, daily at weekends
channel.itunes:summary: The day’s top stories from BBC News. Delivered twice a day on weekdays, daily at weekends
channel.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Scramble to find survivors after Turkey and Syria earthquakes
item.description: Turkey declares a state of emergency as efforts to rescue people continue in the wake of Monday's devastating earthquakes. The UN warns that the flow of aid into north-west Syria has been disrupted because of damage to roads. Also: Russia's foreign minister is in Mali, and the biggest collection of Vermeer paintings is going on show.
item.itunes:subtitle: Turkey declares a state of emergency as efforts to rescue people continue
item.itunes:summary: Turkey declares a state of emergency as efforts to rescue people continue in the wake of Monday's devastating earthquakes. The UN warns that the flow of aid into north-west Syria has been disrupted because of damage to roads. Also: Russia's foreign minister is in Mali, and the biggest collection of Vermeer paintings is going on show.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Rescuers work through the night after earthquakes hit Turkey and Syria
item.description: Rescue teams are racing to save people trapped beneath rubble after thousands of buildings collapsed in both countries. Also: China accused of indoctrinating a million Tibetan children, and the novelist Salman Rushdie gives first interview since 2022 stabbing.
item.itunes:subtitle: World leaders have pledged to send aid
item.itunes:summary: Rescue teams are racing to save people trapped beneath rubble after thousands of buildings collapsed in both countries. Also: China accused of indoctrinating a million Tibetan children, and the novelist Salman Rushdie gives first interview since 2022 stabbing.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: More than 2,000 dead after major earthquakes in Turkey and Syria
item.description: Rescuers are racing to save people trapped beneath the rubble and calling for international support. Also: Beijing confirms another high altitude observation balloon was also from China and the hidden history of the 'real' French revolution, being brought into the open.
item.itunes:subtitle: A rescue operation is under way across southern Turkey after a 7.8 magnitude quake struck
item.itunes:summary: Rescuers are racing to save people trapped beneath the rubble and calling for international support. Also: Beijing confirms another high altitude observation balloon was also from China and the hidden history of the 'real' French revolution, being brought into the open.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Turkey earthquake edition
item.description: Two devastating earthquakes rip through south-eastern Turkey and northern Syria. Thousands have died and many more are injured. There have been appeals for international rescue support and aid.
item.itunes:subtitle: Two devastating earthquakes rip through south-eastern Turkey and northern Syria
item.itunes:summary: Two devastating earthquakes rip through south-eastern Turkey and northern Syria. Thousands have died and many more are injured. There have been appeals for international rescue support and aid.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Some anti-government protesters pardoned in Iran
item.description: The Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei issued them in response to a proposal by the head of the judiciary. Also: Pakistan's former president and military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, has died in exile at the age of seventy-nine, and a prominent British family has paid reparations and apologised to Grenada for their historic links with the slave trade.
item.itunes:subtitle: It follows a proposal by the head of the judiciary
item.itunes:summary: The Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei issued them in response to a proposal by the head of the judiciary. Also: Pakistan's former president and military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, has died in exile at the age of seventy-nine, and a prominent British family has paid reparations and apologised to Grenada for their historic links with the slave trade.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US shoots down Chinese balloon over Atlantic
item.description: Beijing denies Washington's claims it was being used to spy on the US. Also: Thousands of Israelis protest in Tel Aviv against the plans by the Netanyahu government to give itself more powers over appointing judges, and the English National Opera prepares to stage a newly translated version of Wagner's The Rhinegold.
item.itunes:subtitle: Beijing denies Washington's claims it was being used to spy on the US
item.itunes:summary: Beijing denies Washington's claims it was being used to spy on the US. Also: Thousands of Israelis protest in Tel Aviv against the plans by the Netanyahu government to give itself more powers over appointing judges, and the English National Opera prepares to stage a newly translated version of Wagner's The Rhinegold.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Chinese balloon flight violated US sovereignty and international law -- Blinken
item.description: US Secretary of State accuses Beijing of acting irresponsibly and postpones an upcoming trip to China. Also: The US will provide Ukraine with longer range guided rockets to help Kyiv take back Russian-occupied territory, and remembering the Spanish designer Paco Rabanne who has died aged 88.
item.itunes:subtitle: US Secretary of State accuses Beijing of acting irresponsibly
item.itunes:summary: US Secretary of State accuses Beijing of acting irresponsibly and postpones an upcoming trip to China. Also: The US will provide Ukraine with longer range guided rockets to help Kyiv take back Russian-occupied territory, and remembering the Spanish designer Paco Rabanne who has died aged 88.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine's President pushes for early entry on EU membership at Kyiv summit
item.description: EU says Ukraine has made "considerable efforts" towards membership. Also: Pope Francis is visiting South Sudan together with other Christian leaders, and meet Bobi, the world's oldest dog.
item.itunes:subtitle: EU says Ukraine has made "considerable efforts" towards membership
item.itunes:summary: EU says Ukraine has made "considerable efforts" towards membership. Also: Pope Francis is visiting South Sudan together with other Christian leaders, and meet Bobi, the world's oldest dog.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Israeli Attorney General scathing of planned legal reforms
item.description: Gali Baharav-Miara said the proposals would gravely damage the country's system of checks and balances and give the government unlimited power. Also: The Republican held House Of Representatives votes to oust the high profile Democratic representative Ilhan Omar from the foreign affairs committee, and the discovery of Yiddish songs not heard since World War II.
item.itunes:subtitle: Overhaul would gravely damage the system of checks and balances.
item.itunes:summary: Gali Baharav-Miara said the proposals would gravely damage the country's system of checks and balances and give the government unlimited power. Also: The Republican held House Of Representatives votes to oust the high profile Democratic representative Ilhan Omar from the foreign affairs committee, and the discovery of Yiddish songs not heard since World War II.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US secures deal to boost military presence in Philippines
item.description: The agreement gives the Americans access to four new bases not far from Taiwan, where there are growing fears of a Chinese invasion. Also, a senior former Russian army officer says he witnessed soldiers torturing Ukrainian prisoners, and scientists in the UK say they've found evidence of the bird flu virus infecting some mammals.
item.itunes:subtitle: The agreement gives the Americans access to four new bases not far from Taiwan
item.itunes:summary: The agreement gives the Americans access to four new bases not far from Taiwan, where there are growing fears of a Chinese invasion. Also, a senior former Russian army officer says he witnessed soldiers torturing Ukrainian prisoners, and scientists in the UK say they've found evidence of the bird flu virus infecting some mammals.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Tyre Nichols' family demand policing reform bill at funeral
item.description: The mother of the man who died after being beaten by police in Memphis gave a tearful address at his funeral. Also: Switzerland holds its annual sirens day, and do you know how much caffeine there is in your daily cup of coffee?
item.itunes:subtitle: US Vice-President Kamala Harris was among the mourners
item.itunes:summary: The mother of the man who died after being beaten by police in Memphis gave a tearful address at his funeral. Also: Switzerland holds its annual sirens day, and do you know how much caffeine there is in your daily cup of coffee?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine: Police raid oligarch's home
item.description: A series of anti-corruption raids have been carried out in Ukraine targeting prominent figures including a billionaire backer of President Vlodymyr Zelensky. Opposition activists in Myanmar take part in a 'silent strike ' to mark two years since the military junta overthrew the democratically-elected government, a once in a fifty thousand year chance to see 'the green comet', and we look at the alarming world of deep fakes.
item.itunes:subtitle: A series of anti-corruption raids have been carried out in Ukraine
item.itunes:summary: A series of anti-corruption raids have been carried out in Ukraine targeting prominent figures including a billionaire backer of President Vlodymyr Zelensky. Opposition activists in Myanmar take part in a 'silent strike ' to mark two years since the military junta overthrew the democratically-elected government, a once in a fifty thousand year chance to see 'the green comet', and we look at the alarming world of deep fakes.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Top US diplomat says Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank hinders peace prospects
item.description: The US Secretary of state Antony Blinken met the Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas in Ramallah. Also: the Hollywood actor Alec Baldwin is charged with involuntary manslaughter over shooting on Rust film set, and the dangers of taking your pet parrot to the local park.
item.itunes:subtitle: Israel's new government aims to strengthen settlements
item.itunes:summary: The US Secretary of state Antony Blinken met the Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas in Ramallah. Also: the Hollywood actor Alec Baldwin is charged with involuntary manslaughter over shooting on Rust film set, and the dangers of taking your pet parrot to the local park.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine accused of using land-mines to fight Russia's invasion
item.description: Human Rights Watch says the mines were scattered in and around the city of Izyum while it was occupied by Russia. Also: Strikes and demonstrations in France to protest against raising the retirement age to 64, and the bed made for British monarchs that was lost for decades.
item.itunes:subtitle: Human Rights Watch says the mines were scattered in Izyum while it was occupied by Russia
item.itunes:summary: Human Rights Watch says the mines were scattered in and around the city of Izyum while it was occupied by Russia. Also: Strikes and demonstrations in France to protest against raising the retirement age to 64, and the bed made for British monarchs that was lost for decades.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Top US diplomat calls for calm after days of Israeli-Palestinian violence
item.description: The US Secretary of State Antony Blinken repeated the importance of a "two-state solution" to resolve the conflict. Also: Brazil's Bolsonaro seeks six-month US tourist visa, and the last Boeing 747 jumbo jet rolls off the production line.
item.itunes:subtitle: Talks were held in Jerusalem between Antony Blinken and Benjamin Netanyahu
item.itunes:summary: The US Secretary of State Antony Blinken repeated the importance of a "two-state solution" to resolve the conflict. Also: Brazil's Bolsonaro seeks six-month US tourist visa, and the last Boeing 747 jumbo jet rolls off the production line.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Thirty two killed in Pakistan mosque attack
item.description: At least one hundred and fifty were also injured in the explosion in the city of Peshawar. Also: the US Secretary of State Antony Blinken arrives in Israel, and the Chinese province of Sichuan tries to boost its population rate.
item.itunes:subtitle: At least one hundred and fifty were also injured in the explosion in the city of Peshawar
item.itunes:summary: At least one hundred and fifty were also injured in the explosion in the city of Peshawar. Also: the US Secretary of State Antony Blinken arrives in Israel, and the Chinese province of Sichuan tries to boost its population rate.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Brexit: Three years on
item.description: The UK formally left the European Union on the 31 January 2020. We look at what Brexit means for Britain's place in the world today. Has it unleashed the UK's global potential? Or has it been the disaster that many opponents predicted? BBC World Service presenter Oliver Conway, political correspondent Rob Watson, Global Trade correspondent Dharshini David, and Europe editor Katya Adler answer questions from Global News Podcast listeners.
item.itunes:subtitle: A success or a disaster? We ask our correspondents and answer listener questions
item.itunes:summary: The UK formally left the European Union on the 31 January 2020. We look at what Brexit means for Britain's place in the world today. Has it unleashed the UK's global potential? Or has it been the disaster that many opponents predicted? BBC World Service presenter Oliver Conway, political correspondent Rob Watson, Global Trade correspondent Dharshini David, and Europe editor Katya Adler answer questions from Global News Podcast listeners.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: British PM sacks Zahawi for 'serious breach' over tax
item.description: Nadhim Zahawi is sacked as Conservative party chairman after an inquiry finds he failed to disclose an investigation into his tax affairs. Also: Israel to speed up gun applications after attacks, and the guitarist Tom Verlaine dies aged 73.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mr Zahawi had admitted paying a penalty to tax authorities
item.itunes:summary: Nadhim Zahawi is sacked as Conservative party chairman after an inquiry finds he failed to disclose an investigation into his tax affairs. Also: Israel to speed up gun applications after attacks, and the guitarist Tom Verlaine dies aged 73.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Netanyahu warns of 'swift' response to Palestinian attacks
item.description: The Israeli Prime Minister was speaking as he convened his security cabinet. Also: The former NATO general and strong EU supporter, Petr Pavel, has been elected president in the Czech Republic following a bruising campaign, and can AI replace journalists?
item.itunes:subtitle: The Israeli Prime Minister was speaking as he convened his security cabinet
item.itunes:summary: The Israeli Prime Minister was speaking as he convened his security cabinet. Also: The former NATO general and strong EU supporter, Petr Pavel, has been elected president in the Czech Republic following a bruising campaign, and can AI replace journalists?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Seven killed in Jerusalem synagogue attack
item.description: Israeli police killed the suspect as he tried to escape. It comes amid escalating violence in Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories. Also: The video is released of police officers in the US city of Memphis savagely beating a black motorist, Tyre Nichols - who later died, and as the world marked Holocaust Memorial Day we hear about the growing numbers of people who think the holocaust was a myth.
item.itunes:subtitle: Israeli police killed the suspect as he tried to escape
item.itunes:summary: Israeli police killed the suspect as he tried to escape. It comes amid escalating violence in Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories. Also: The video is released of police officers in the US city of Memphis savagely beating a black motorist, Tyre Nichols - who later died, and as the world marked Holocaust Memorial Day we hear about the growing numbers of people who think the holocaust was a myth.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Fears mount of fresh Israel-Palestinian violence
item.description: Israeli air raids and Palestinian rocket fire raise tensions. The violence follows a deadly Israeli army raid on the occupied West Bank. Also: Shares slump in one of India's biggest companies after allegations of financial misconduct -- and the mystery of the miraculously growing Vladimir Putin.
item.itunes:subtitle: Israeli air raids and Palestinian rocket fire raise tensions
item.itunes:summary: Israeli air raids and Palestinian rocket fire raise tensions. The violence follows a deadly Israeli army raid on the occupied West Bank. Also: Shares slump in one of India's biggest companies after allegations of financial misconduct -- and the mystery of the miraculously growing Vladimir Putin.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Five police officers charged over Tyre Nichols' death in Memphis
item.description: The 29-year-old was stopped on 7 January for reckless driving, and died three days later. Also: fear of flare-up after deadly Israeli raid in Jenin, and why do some men wear shorts in cold weather?
item.itunes:subtitle: A video of his arrest is expected to be released
item.itunes:summary: The 29-year-old was stopped on 7 January for reckless driving, and died three days later. Also: fear of flare-up after deadly Israeli raid in Jenin, and why do some men wear shorts in cold weather?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Deadly West Bank clashes in Jenin
item.description: At least nine Palestinians were killed during an Israeli military raid, one of them an elderly woman. Israel said its troops went in to arrest Islamic Jihad militants. The Palestinian authorities accused them of a massacre. Also: A sharp rise in Myanmar's opium harvest, and why elephants aren’t just big and beautiful -- but vital for biodiversity too.
item.itunes:subtitle: At least nine Palestinians killed during an Israeli military raid
item.itunes:summary: At least nine Palestinians were killed during an Israeli military raid, one of them an elderly woman. Israel said its troops went in to arrest Islamic Jihad militants. The Palestinian authorities accused them of a massacre. Also: A sharp rise in Myanmar's opium harvest, and why elephants aren’t just big and beautiful -- but vital for biodiversity too.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US joins Germany in sending tanks to Ukraine
item.description: Ukraine hails the announcements of the tanks as a turning point, while Russia says they are a provocation. Also: Lebanon's top prosecutor lays charges against the judge who is investigating the 2020 Beirut port explosion, and the Sesame Street co-creator Lloyd Morrisett dies aged 93.
item.itunes:subtitle: The United States will deliver 31 Abrams tanks to the battlefield
item.itunes:summary: Ukraine hails the announcements of the tanks as a turning point, while Russia says they are a provocation. Also: Lebanon's top prosecutor lays charges against the judge who is investigating the 2020 Beirut port explosion, and the Sesame Street co-creator Lloyd Morrisett dies aged 93.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: German Leopard tank training for Ukrainian troops to begin soon
item.description: German Chancellor confirms his country will send battle tanks to Ukraine. Also: A BBC investigation finds evidence of alarming coronavirus death rates in rural China, and how humans share common sign language with wild chimps and bonobos.
item.itunes:subtitle: German Chancellor confirms his country will send battle tanks to Ukraine
item.itunes:summary: German Chancellor confirms his country will send battle tanks to Ukraine. Also: A BBC investigation finds evidence of alarming coronavirus death rates in rural China, and how humans share common sign language with wild chimps and bonobos.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Germany approves Leopard tanks for Ukraine - reports
item.description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz has faced weeks of pressure from Kyiv and its allies. Also: Classified documents have been found at the home of the former US vice-president Mike Pence in the latest discovery of secret papers, and we hear who's been nominated for this year's Oscars.
item.itunes:subtitle: Chancellor Olaf Scholz has faced weeks of international pressure
item.itunes:summary: Chancellor Olaf Scholz has faced weeks of pressure from Kyiv and its allies. Also: Classified documents have been found at the home of the former US vice-president Mike Pence in the latest discovery of secret papers, and we hear who's been nominated for this year's Oscars.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukrainian officials quit in anti-corruption drive
item.description: President Zelensky has removed five regional governors and four deputy ministers in a reshuffle. Also, the Afghan authorities say more than 120 people have died because of freezing temperatures, and instead of flowers, why one bride in the Philippines chose to have a bouquet of onions!
item.itunes:subtitle: President Zelensky removes five regional governors and four deputy ministers
item.itunes:summary: President Zelensky has removed five regional governors and four deputy ministers in a reshuffle. Also, the Afghan authorities say more than 120 people have died because of freezing temperatures, and instead of flowers, why one bride in the Philippines chose to have a bouquet of onions!
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US court convicts far-right militia members of seditious conspiracy
item.description: The four men - who belong to the Oath Keepers group - were charged in connection with the attack on the Capitol two years ago. Also: Ukraine's foreign minister appeals to countries with Leopard tanks to make a formal request to Germany to allow them to hand the tanks over, and a four-year-old English boy with an unusual IQ.
item.itunes:subtitle: The four men were charged in connection with the attack on the Capitol two years ago.
item.itunes:summary: The four men - who belong to the Oath Keepers group - were charged in connection with the attack on the Capitol two years ago. Also: Ukraine's foreign minister appeals to countries with Leopard tanks to make a formal request to Germany to allow them to hand the tanks over, and a four-year-old English boy with an unusual IQ.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Poland to ask Berlin's permission to send tanks to Ukraine
item.description: Germany's permission is required, because it built and sold the vehicles originally. But the Polish government has suggested it might ignore this and send the tanks anyway. Also, we head to one of the eastern Ukrainian towns retaken from Russian forces, and Japan's prime minister warns the declining birth rate is putting the future of the country at risk.
item.itunes:subtitle: Germany's permission is required, because it built and sold the vehicles originally
item.itunes:summary: Germany's permission is required, because it built and sold the vehicles originally. But the Polish government has suggested it might ignore this and send the tanks anyway. Also, we head to one of the eastern Ukrainian towns retaken from Russian forces, and Japan's prime minister warns the declining birth rate is putting the future of the country at risk.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Body of main suspect in California mass shooting reportedly found
item.description: It's reported police found the body in a van as they were continuing their search for the wanted man. Also: Netanyahu sacks Israeli interior minister after court ruling, and milk may have fuelled a growth spurt in ancient Europeans.
item.itunes:subtitle: Police to make official confirmation regarding developments
item.itunes:summary: It's reported police found the body in a van as they were continuing their search for the wanted man. Also: Netanyahu sacks Israeli interior minister after court ruling, and milk may have fuelled a growth spurt in ancient Europeans.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Thousands protest against Netanyahu's justice plans
item.description: Protestors say plans to limit the powers of the Israeli judiciary are a direct attack on democracy. Also: Brazil's army chief sacked after Congress riots, and why are baguettes such an important part of French life?
item.itunes:subtitle: Benjamin Netanyahu returned to power last month
item.itunes:summary: Protestors say plans to limit the powers of the Israeli judiciary are a direct attack on democracy. Also: Brazil's army chief sacked after Congress riots, and why are baguettes such an important part of French life?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Zelensky will 'keep pushing' for German tanks
item.description: The Ukrainian president spoke after a meeting of allied nations failed to agree to give Kyiv modern tanks. Also: the quest for life on Jupiter's icy moons, and why walking upright isn't that hard for baboons.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Ukrainian president spoke after allied nations failed to agree to give Kyiv tanks
item.itunes:summary: The Ukrainian president spoke after a meeting of allied nations failed to agree to give Kyiv modern tanks. Also: the quest for life on Jupiter's icy moons, and why walking upright isn't that hard for baboons.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine: 'Give us tanks' says Zelensky
item.description: Kyiv's allies are meeting at a US airbase to hash out further military support. Also: A court in Romania extends police detention for the influencer, Andrew Tate, and his brother, and a giant toad weighing more than two and a half kilos has been found in a north Australian rainforest.
item.itunes:subtitle: Kyiv's allies are meeting at a US airbase to hash out further military support
item.itunes:summary: Kyiv's allies are meeting at a US airbase to hash out further military support. Also: A court in Romania extends police detention for the influencer, Andrew Tate, and his brother, and a giant toad weighing more than two and a half kilos has been found in a north Australian rainforest.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Alec Baldwin to be charged over fatal shooting
item.description: The actor is being charged with involuntary manslaughter over a cinematographer's death on a film set. Also: scientists say light pollution has reduced the number of stars we can see, and bringing back to life General de Gaulle's BBC war time broadcast.
item.itunes:subtitle: The actor is being charged with involuntary manslaughter over a cinematographer's death
item.itunes:summary: The actor is being charged with involuntary manslaughter over a cinematographer's death on a film set. Also: scientists say light pollution has reduced the number of stars we can see, and bringing back to life General de Gaulle's BBC war time broadcast.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Strikes in France to halt pension age rise
item.description: President Macron's plans raise retirement age from 62 to 64. Also: New Zealand's prime minister, Jacinda Ardern, steps down -- she says because of burnout, and researchers say investing more in carbon capture and storage technologies is vital to limit global warming.
item.itunes:subtitle: President Macron's plans raise retirement age to 64
item.itunes:summary: President Macron's plans raise retirement age from 62 to 64. Also: New Zealand's prime minister, Jacinda Ardern, steps down -- she says because of burnout, and researchers say investing more in carbon capture and storage technologies is vital to limit global warming.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine: Zelensky appeals to allies to quicken the delivery of heavy weapons
item.description: Zelensky told delegates at the World Economic Forum in Davos: "It was not us who started the war but it is us who will have to end it." Also: Israel's top court has blocked the appointment of an ultra-Orthodox politician as a minister in Benjamin Netanyahu's coalition government because of a recent criminal conviction and staying in Israel scientists there have created a robot that can detect smells.
item.itunes:subtitle: President Zelensky has appealed to western allies to hurry the delivery of heavy weapons
item.itunes:summary: Zelensky told delegates at the World Economic Forum in Davos: "It was not us who started the war but it is us who will have to end it." Also: Israel's top court has blocked the appointment of an ultra-Orthodox politician as a minister in Benjamin Netanyahu's coalition government because of a recent criminal conviction and staying in Israel scientists there have created a robot that can detect smells.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukrainian officials killed in helicopter crash
item.description: Ukraine's interior minister is among the dead. The crash happened near a kindergarten in an eastern suburb of Kyiv. Also: The Philippines Nobel prize winner, Maria Ressa, is acquitted in a move hailed as a victory for press freedom, why seals have been attacking humans in South Africa, and international diplomacy in a sauna.
item.itunes:subtitle: The interior minister is among the dead
item.itunes:summary: Ukraine's interior minister is among the dead. The crash happened near a kindergarten in an eastern suburb of Kyiv. Also: The Philippines Nobel prize winner, Maria Ressa, is acquitted in a move hailed as a victory for press freedom, why seals have been attacking humans in South Africa, and international diplomacy in a sauna.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: EU strikes deal with suspect in corruption scandal
item.description: Former Italian politician Pier Panzeri promises to tell investigators who else was involved. Also: aid agencies partially resume work in Afghanistan, the funeral of an LGBTQ activist in Kenya, and a BBC documentary brings fresh insight into the 2002 Gujarat riots.
item.itunes:subtitle: Former politician Pier Panzeri promises to tell investigators who else was involved
item.itunes:summary: Former Italian politician Pier Panzeri promises to tell investigators who else was involved. Also: aid agencies partially resume work in Afghanistan, the funeral of an LGBTQ activist in Kenya, and a BBC documentary brings fresh insight into the 2002 Gujarat riots.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China's population falls
item.description: China's population falls for the first time in 60 years. Also, the Belarussian opposition leader on trial - and counting walruses.
item.itunes:subtitle: The country's headcount declines for the first time in 60 years
item.itunes:summary: China's population falls for the first time in 60 years. Also, the Belarussian opposition leader on trial - and counting walruses.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Italy's Mafia boss arrest hailed as 'major blow' to crime
item.description: Celebrations have continued across Sicily at the news of the capture of Matteo Messina Denaro. Also: Could Nasa technology help reduce the risks of older people falling over? And the Australian woman who's just run the entire length of her country - a marathon every day for a hundred and fifty days.
item.itunes:subtitle: Celebrations continue across Sicily at the news of the capture of Matteo Messina Denaro
item.itunes:summary: Celebrations have continued across Sicily at the news of the capture of Matteo Messina Denaro. Also: Could Nasa technology help reduce the risks of older people falling over? And the Australian woman who's just run the entire length of her country - a marathon every day for a hundred and fifty days.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Italy's most-wanted mafia boss arrested in Sicily
item.description: Matteo Messina Denaro is captured after 30 years on the run. More than 100 members of the armed forces were involved in his arrest. Also: a British Police officer admits to multiple rapes and sexual assaults over the course of almost two decades, and conservation organisations are seeking volunteers to become 'walrus detectives'.
item.itunes:subtitle: Matteo Messina Denaro is captured after 30 years on the run
item.itunes:summary: Matteo Messina Denaro is captured after 30 years on the run. More than 100 members of the armed forces were involved in his arrest. Also: a British Police officer admits to multiple rapes and sexual assaults over the course of almost two decades, and conservation organisations are seeking volunteers to become 'walrus detectives'.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Nepal mourns its worst air disaster in 30 years
item.description: The Yeti Airlines flight came down near the town of Pokhara on Sunday morning. Also: a bomb attack on worshippers in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu pushes ahead with controversial reforms, and Jordan’s plans to increase tourism.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Yeti Airlines flight came down near the town of Pokhara on Sunday morning
item.itunes:summary: The Yeti Airlines flight came down near the town of Pokhara on Sunday morning. Also: a bomb attack on worshippers in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu pushes ahead with controversial reforms, and Jordan’s plans to increase tourism.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russia fires new waves of missiles across Ukraine
item.description: Several Ukrainian cities were struck including Dnipro, where an apartment block was hit. Also: more classified material found at Biden's home, and Ray Cordeiro -- the world's longest working disc jockey -- dies aged 98.
item.itunes:subtitle: Emergency blackouts were imposed in much of the country
item.itunes:summary: Several Ukrainian cities were struck including Dnipro, where an apartment block was hit. Also: more classified material found at Biden's home, and Ray Cordeiro -- the world's longest working disc jockey -- dies aged 98.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump's company fined $1.6m for tax crimes
item.description: The Trump Organization was found guilty of fraud and falsifying business records. Also: Russia claims victory in battle for Soledar, and why does chocolate feel so good to eat?
item.itunes:subtitle: Neither Donald Trump or his family were part of the court trial
item.itunes:summary: The Trump Organization was found guilty of fraud and falsifying business records. Also: Russia claims victory in battle for Soledar, and why does chocolate feel so good to eat?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine defence minister: We are a de facto member of Nato alliance
item.description: Oleksii Reznikov says he's confident the west will supply the heavy weapons needed to defeat Russia. Also: Kazakhstan has stripped the former president Nursultan Nazarbayev of his honorary status as head of the nation, and the man accused of killing Japan's former prime minister, Shinzo Abe, has been charged with murder.
item.itunes:subtitle: Oleksii Reznikov says he's confident the west will supply the heavy weapons needed
item.itunes:summary: Oleksii Reznikov says he's confident the west will supply the heavy weapons needed to defeat Russia. Also: Kazakhstan has stripped the former president Nursultan Nazarbayev of his honorary status as head of the nation, and the man accused of killing Japan's former prime minister, Shinzo Abe, has been charged with murder.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Special counsel to investigate Biden files
item.description: It follows the discovery of classified material in the US president's home and an office. Also: The Brazilian president says the protesters who ransacked government buildings on Sunday had inside help from members of the security forces, and the hunt for a cat that's been missing in an airport in Bolivia for a month.
item.itunes:subtitle: It follows the discovery of classified material at two addresses
item.itunes:summary: It follows the discovery of classified material in the US president's home and an office. Also: The Brazilian president says the protesters who ransacked government buildings on Sunday had inside help from members of the security forces, and the hunt for a cat that's been missing in an airport in Bolivia for a month.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UAE oil boss to lead UN climate summit
item.description: Climate change campaigners express outrage at Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber's appointment. Also: a French huntsman who killed a man he mistook for a wild boar avoids prison, and we look back at the life of the influential British guitarist Jeff Beck.
item.itunes:subtitle: Climate change campaigners express outrage at Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber's appointment
item.itunes:summary: Climate change campaigners express outrage at Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber's appointment. Also: a French huntsman who killed a man he mistook for a wild boar avoids prison, and we look back at the life of the influential British guitarist Jeff Beck.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine war: Fighting rages for control of Soledar
item.description: Ukraine disputes new claim by Russian mercenary group, Wagner, that the town has been captured. Also: Police are on high alert in Brazil as protests are held by supporters of the former president, Jair Bolsonaro, and the seal that's eating its way through all the fish in an English lake.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ukraine disputes new claim by Russian mercenary group that the town has been captured
item.itunes:summary: Ukraine disputes new claim by Russian mercenary group, Wagner, that the town has been captured. Also: Police are on high alert in Brazil as protests are held by supporters of the former president, Jair Bolsonaro, and the seal that's eating its way through all the fish in an English lake.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Soledar: Reports from Eastern Ukraine hint at rift in pro-Russian forces
item.description: Russia's defence ministry and the mercenary Wagner Group give competing versions of events. Also: Uganda says the Ebola epidemic that killed 56 people is over, and the workers in Japan getting a huge pay rise.
item.itunes:subtitle: Russia's defence ministry and the Wagner Group give competing versions of events
item.itunes:summary: Russia's defence ministry and the mercenary Wagner Group give competing versions of events. Also: Uganda says the Ebola epidemic that killed 56 people is over, and the workers in Japan getting a huge pay rise.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Chinese crematoriums 'swamped' as Covid surges
item.description: The revelations follow new detailed analysis of satellite imagery by the Washington Post into the low official death rate. Also: Up to 100 Ukrainian soldiers will arrive in the US as early as next week to start training for the Patriot missile system, and the singing bus driver who has become an internet sensation.
item.itunes:subtitle: It follows new detailed analysis of satellite imagery by the Washington Post
item.itunes:summary: The revelations follow new detailed analysis of satellite imagery by the Washington Post into the low official death rate. Also: Up to 100 Ukrainian soldiers will arrive in the US as early as next week to start training for the Patriot missile system, and the singing bus driver who has become an internet sensation.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China accuses countries of discrimination over Covid
item.description: Beijing suspends visas for some of its neighbours amid surging coronavirus infections. Also: heavy casualties in Ukraine as both sides resort to fierce trench warfare in the east, and it's finally here! Prince Harry's autobiography goes on sale.
item.itunes:subtitle: Beijing suspends visas for some of its neighbours amid surging coronavirus infections
item.itunes:summary: Beijing suspends visas for some of its neighbours amid surging coronavirus infections. Also: heavy casualties in Ukraine as both sides resort to fierce trench warfare in the east, and it's finally here! Prince Harry's autobiography goes on sale.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Mass arrests in Brazil following Congress attack
item.description: Protest camps outside military barracks across the country are also being dismantled. Also: Western countries register strong protests with Iran for executing young people after anti-government protests, and why people in Ghana are angry with the American rapper Meek Mill.
item.itunes:subtitle: Protest camps outside military barracks across the country are also being dismantled
item.itunes:summary: Protest camps outside military barracks across the country are also being dismantled. Also: Western countries register strong protests with Iran for executing young people after anti-government protests, and why people in Ghana are angry with the American rapper Meek Mill.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Brazil police surround protest camps after Congress attack
item.description: Thousands of demonstrators ransacked government buildings in the capital on Sunday. Also: Pakistan asks the international community for billions of dollars of support after last year’s devastating floods, and former employees of a Belarusian news website which covered mass protests against the President have gone on trial.
item.itunes:subtitle: Thousands of demonstrators ransacked government buildings in the capital on Sunday
item.itunes:summary: Thousands of demonstrators ransacked government buildings in the capital on Sunday. Also: Pakistan asks the international community for billions of dollars of support after last year’s devastating floods, and former employees of a Belarusian news website which covered mass protests against the President have gone on trial.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Tear gas fired in Brazil as Bolsonaro supporters storm Congress
item.description: Thousands of demonstrators broke into Brazil's Congress, Supreme Court and presidential palace. Also: Kyiv denies Russia claim it killed hundreds of Ukrainian soldiers in an attack, and are you ready to pre-order your first flying car?
item.itunes:subtitle: The Brazilian president has vowed to punish the perpetrators
item.itunes:summary: Thousands of demonstrators broke into Brazil's Congress, Supreme Court and presidential palace. Also: Kyiv denies Russia claim it killed hundreds of Ukrainian soldiers in an attack, and are you ready to pre-order your first flying car?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Special episode: Indigenous peoples
item.description: We hear from our Indigenous and tribal listeners around the world, as we mark US Indigenous Peoples’ Day. We also meet an Amazon tribe defending their land from illegal loggers; a Maori singer who makes pop music in his traditional language; Native American chefs bringing cultural foods to the restaurant scene; and more.
item.itunes:subtitle: We hear from Indigenous listeners around the world as we mark US Indigenous Peoples’ Day
item.itunes:summary: We hear from our Indigenous and tribal listeners around the world, as we mark US Indigenous Peoples’ Day. We also meet an Amazon tribe defending their land from illegal loggers; a Maori singer who makes pop music in his traditional language; Native American chefs bringing cultural foods to the restaurant scene; and more.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Live special episode: Cost of living
item.description: The global price crisis. Our first ever “live audience show” – recorded in Malaysia. Listeners around the world and in the audience in Kuala Lumpur share their experiences and ask questions about spiralling costs and what can be done. Hear from our panel of BBC correspondents. What are the implications of the increases in food and fuel prices? How are governments and communities responding - and what does the future look like?
item.itunes:subtitle: The global price crisis. Our first ever ”live audience show” – recorded in Malaysia
item.itunes:summary: The global price crisis. Our first ever “live audience show” – recorded in Malaysia. Listeners around the world and in the audience in Kuala Lumpur share their experiences and ask questions about spiralling costs and what can be done. Hear from our panel of BBC correspondents. What are the implications of the increases in food and fuel prices? How are governments and communities responding - and what does the future look like?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Special episode: Abortion rights around the world
item.description:
In June, the US Supreme Court overruled Roe v Wade and ended the constitutional right to abortion in America. In a special episode, we investigate the changing dynamic of abortion rights globally in countries like Colombia, China and Ireland. We'll also be examining the restrictions still faced by women in Africa and places like Malta and El Salvador.
Audio for this episode was updated on 4 July 2022, due to a factual error in an earlier version.
item.itunes:subtitle: We investigate the changing dynamic of abortion rights globally
item.itunes:summary:
In June, the US Supreme Court overruled Roe v Wade and ended the constitutional right to abortion in America. In a special episode, we investigate the changing dynamic of abortion rights globally in countries like Colombia, China and Ireland. We'll also be examining the restrictions still faced by women in Africa and places like Malta and El Salvador.
Audio for this episode was updated on 4 July 2022, due to a factual error in an earlier version.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Young voices special
item.description:
Is the nuclear threat real? What does Putin want? Who is winning the war in Ukraine? We took questions on the invasion from young people around the world and looked for answers from BBC correspondents.
Jackie Leonard speaks to Martin Forster, a senior child psychologist with the healthcare company, Kry, in Sweden. Listeners' questions are tackled by Vitaliy Shevchenko, Paul Adams, Theo Leggett, Lyse Doucet and Mark Lowen.
item.itunes:subtitle: We took questions on Ukraine from young people around the world
item.itunes:summary:
Is the nuclear threat real? What does Putin want? Who is winning the war in Ukraine? We took questions on the invasion from young people around the world and looked for answers from BBC correspondents.
Jackie Leonard speaks to Martin Forster, a senior child psychologist with the healthcare company, Kry, in Sweden. Listeners' questions are tackled by Vitaliy Shevchenko, Paul Adams, Theo Leggett, Lyse Doucet and Mark Lowen.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Special: Global News Ukrainecast part 2
item.description:
A month since the Russian invasion of Ukraine, we are collaborating with Ukrainecast again. We answer more of your questions.
Jackie Leonard, presenter of the Global News Podcast, alongside Gabriel Gatehouse and Vitaliy Shevchenko from Ukrainecast, guide us through questions about civilian life in the country, military tactics, and the international response to the invasion.
BBC chief international correspondent, Lyse Doucet, joins us from Kyiv to talk through what is happening on the ground there, and BBC security correspondent Frank Gardner, tells us the latest on the physical and information war.
This episode was made by Chris Flynn. The studio director was Ash Taylor. The assistant editor was Sam Bonham.
item.itunes:subtitle: We answer more of your questions about Ukraine
item.itunes:summary:

BBC chief international correspondent, Lyse Doucet, joins us from Kyiv to talk through what is happening on the ground there, and BBC security correspondent Frank Gardner, tells us the latest on the physical and information war.
This episode was made by Chris Flynn. The studio director was Ash Taylor. The assistant editor was Sam Bonham.

item.title: Special: Global News Ukrainecast
item.description: BBC correspondents tackle questions from listeners around the world about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Jackie Leonard speaks to Gabriel Gatehouse, Vitaliy Shevchenko, Lyse Doucet and James Landale.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine: On the brink of war?
item.description: Our experts in Moscow, Kyiv and London answer your questions about the crisis.

item.itunes:summary: Our experts in Moscow, Kyiv and London answer your questions about the crisis.

item.title: Omicron versus the world: Your questions answered
item.description: As the Omicron variant spreads around the world and cases surge, BBC correspondents tell us how Covid-19 is impacting our lives, our businesses and our economies.
item.itunes:subtitle: The facts, the science, the politics, the economics and the myths
item.itunes:summary: As the Omicron variant spreads around the world and cases surge, BBC correspondents tell us how Covid-19 is impacting our lives, our businesses and our economies.

item.title: Afghanistan Special: Your Questions Answered
item.description:
BBC correspondents answer your questions about the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan. We ask how did the Taliban overthrow the Afghan government so quickly? What now for human rights, the economy and international relations?
Photo:People on board an evacuation flight out of Kabul airport, August 21, 2021 Credit:MoD/PA Wire

item.title: Global News Brexitcast
item.description: We team up with the award-winning Brexitcast team to bring you a special update on what Britain leaving the EU means for you. You’ve sent us questions from around the world and Jackie Leonard puts them to the experts from the podcast that’s all about Brexit. There’s also cake, phew. Spread the word! #GlobalNewsPod #Brexitcast Find the Brexitcast podcast here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/brexitcast
